title: Steel firms demand cut in energy costs to save industry and compete with rivals
text:

British steelmakers fork out £55million a year more for electricity than French rivals, a report reveals today.

UK firms also stump up an extra £47million compared with German counterparts, the UK Steel study shows.

Campaigners called for energy costs to be slashed so the fragile industry can take on international competitors on a “level playing field”.

UK steel companies pay 62% more for electricity than Germany firms and 80% more than those in France, according to the 26-page report, The Energy Price Gap - A New Power Deal for UK Steel.

(Image: Getty Images)

It says: “The UK’s energy intensive industries face some of the highest industrial electricity prices in Europe.

“This damages the steel sector’s competitiveness as it is both electro-intensive and highly exposed to international competition, meaning it cannot pass on additional costs to customers.

“With steel producers’ direct competitiveness and levels of investment both being affected, electricity prices have become a major ongoing concern for the sector and its long-term sustainability.”

Despite wholesale prices dropping over the past year, there remains a “persistent gap between UK industrial power prices and those elsewhere”, with German and French steelmakers paying £19 per megawatt-hour and £22/MWh less respectively than those in the UK.

(Image: PA)

British steel firms pay £50/MWh, compared with £31/MWh in Germany and just £28/MWh in France.

A typical steel plant could use more than half a million MWh each year.

For some steel companies, electricity represents the largest cost after raw materials - including workers’ pay.

Experts warn that higher prices mean there is less cash to pump into new equipment and technology.

The burden also puts off potential investors, “severely reducing the sector’s ability to be competitive today and through to the long term”.

UK Steel added: “This ultimately erodes the sector’s future in the UK.”

(Image: PA)

The report says: “UK prices for extra-large industrial users currently stand 56% above the EU average.

“This fact is consistently cited by all UK steel producers as harmful to their competitiveness and an impediment to investment.”

Nearly 32,000 people are directly employed in Britain’s steel industry, which contributes £1.6billion to the economy.

UK Steel director general Gareth Stace said: “Our new report plainly demonstrates that UK steelmakers face systemically and persistently higher electricity prices than our competitors.

(Image: PA)

“Electricity is one of the biggest costs for the steel industry and it damages our competitiveness that we are consistently forced to pay significantly more.

“The Government must act now to provide that level playing field the sector desperately needs.”

Community steelworkers union operations' director Alasdair McDiarmid said: "It's disappointing we're still talking about this difference in energy costs because we've been calling for action for years.

“Our steel industry is continuing to compete with one hand tied behind its back.

“Given all the pressures facing the industry it's high-time the government got real about the steps that must be taken to put UK steel companies on a level playing field with their competitors."

The Mirror has been calling for an energy price cut for steel firms as part of our Save Our Steel campaign, launched in 2015 as the industry was battered by job losses and factory closures.

Last month, the sector suffered a fresh blow as it was announced the Orb Electrical Steels plant in Newport, South Wales, will close after 121 years of steelmaking, along with a service centre in Wolverhampton.

(Image: Scunthorpe Live)

Some 400 jobs were plunged into jeopardy.

Scunthorpe-based British Steel went into liquidation in May but talks continue over a rescue deal which could save more than 4,000 jobs.

Labour MP Stephen Kinnock, whose Aberavon constituency includes Britain's biggest steelworks, Port Talbot, said: “British steelworkers make the best steel in the world but they’re made to do so with one hand tied behind their backs due to the grossly uncompetitive electricity prices that our steel companies are forced to pay.

“It’s an outrage that ministers claim to be standing up for steel whilst doing absolutely nothing about the fact that British steelmakers are paying 80% more for electricity than their French counterparts, and 62% more than the Germans.

“If it were to level the playing field on these costs the Government would, at the stroke of a pen, be enabling the release of an additional £47million of desperately-needed investment into our steel industry.”
description: The trade body called for prices to be slashed so UK companies can become more competitive
